stories.headline: Epstein survivor testified she met Trump at age 14
stories.summary: A child sex abuse survivor from Palm Beach County testified at the Ghislaine Maxwell trial that she met Donald Trump with Jeffrey Epstein at Mar-a-Lago in the 1990s when she was 14 and was once a contestant in Trump’s Miss Teen USA beauty pageant. Using the pseudonym 'Jane,' she stated that Trump never described inappropriate behavior or abuse during the meeting. Jane also participated in the 1998 pageant. Her testimony sheds light on connections between Trump, Epstein, and alleged victims.

stories.headline: $32M on its way to PBC schools
stories.summary: The Palm Beach County School District will receive nearly $32 million in education funding from the Trump administration that had been previously withheld. The funds are part of a $7 billion federal education allocation. The district expressed relief, noting the funds will support critical programs and services for students, families, and educators. The Trump administration had withheld the funds for review by the Office of Management and Budget, despite Congressional approval.

stories.headline: 2 kids found dead, folded in suitcases
stories.summary: Two young children, Felicia Brown, 25, her children Jermaine McNeil, 10, and Ju'Tyra Allen, 6, were victims in a tragic case where the children were found dead and folded in suitcases. Police recovered the children from a canal in Delray Beach, Florida, and also found their brother Jermaine McNeil in a suitcase nearby. The children had been missing, and the incident involved their mother and her boyfriend Clem Beauchamp, an ongoing investigation is underway.

stories.headline: Police officer among dead in NYC shooting
stories.summary: A gunman armed with an M4 rifle entered a Park Avenue skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan, New York City, and fatally shot at least four people, including a police officer, before killing himself. The shooting occurred on July 28 inside a 44-floor building housing NFL headquarters and major financial firms. Preliminary investigations were underway to determine the motive, with some reports suggesting the gunman may have blamed the NFL for an injury.

stories.headline: County plans youth behavioral health center
stories.summary: Santa Fe County is moving toward opening a youth behavioral health center in 2026 after commissioners approved buying a $7 million property for youth case and crisis management. Behavioral health is a significant regional issue with juvenile crime and mental health concerns. The new center aims to provide specialized services, including suicide prevention and youth-specific care, addressing a long-standing gap in local support.

stories.headline: Gallup hospital limits care after Trump order on contract review
stories.summary: A Trump administration policy requiring increased federal oversight on contracts has caused the Gallup Indian Medical Center to reduce surgical beds and restrict birth services due to staffing shortages and immediate care needs. The hospital must also transport patients during birth to other facilities since it is the only birthing center in the city and its services have diminished.

stories.headline: Survey lets residents weigh in on S.F. elections
stories.summary: A new survey invites Santa Fe residents to prioritize key city issues and express their voting intentions for the 2025 local elections. The survey results will guide candidates and forums at Santa Fe Community College and New Mexican media outlets. It is part of a civic engagement initiative to better inform voters about public safety, housing, and other city concerns ahead of the election season.

stories.headline: EPA to roll back rule underpinning climate change laws
stories.summary: EPA administrator Lee Zeldin announced plans to revoke a key 2009 endangerment finding that set limits on greenhouse gas emissions from vehicles and industrial sources. The rollback aims to ease regulations imposed under prior administrations that addressed climate change by limiting emissions. Critics highlight that this move threatens public health and efforts to combat climate change, while proponents see it as regulatory relief for industries.

stories.headline: One losing coverage
stories.summary: The chair of the Fort Marcy neighborhood Kiwanis Club said the annual Zozobra event may forfeit insurance because of concerns that the burning event could damage century-old trees on the site. This issue risks canceling or relocating the event as organizers face a safety hazard debate and strong community opinions about protecting the trees and maintaining the tradition.

stories.headline: E.P.A. To Retract Bedrock Finding On Climate Crisis
stories.summary: The Environmental Protection Agency under Lee Zeldin plans to revoke the 2009 endangerment finding on climate change, which previously mandated limits on greenhouse gas emissions. The move would eliminate the EPA's authority to regulate emissions under the Clean Air Act, sparking concerns about environmental policies and climate change mitigation efforts.

stories.headline: Barring Truce, U.K. to Affirm Palestine State
stories.summary: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced Britain would recognize the state of Palestine in September if Israel does not agree to a cease-fire amid the ongoing conflict with Hamas. The decision marks a significant shift in British policy and comes amid rising international pressure to resolve the Gaza crisis, with calls for a ceasefire and humanitarian relief.

stories.headline: A Battle Over Burial Grounds Rattles the Gates of Hilton Head
stories.summary: Tensions rose in Hilton Head, South Carolina, as African American residents, including Theresa Aigner, contested restrictions on the Gullah Geechee cemetery, a historically African American burial site. The dispute involves efforts by a landowner to limit access, sparking legal actions and community appeals to preserve the cultural and historical significance of the cemetery.

stories.headline: Cash Stipends Did Not Benefit Needy Children
stories.summary: A study revealed that government attempts to help poor children by providing parents with monthly payments under a cash stipend program failed to improve child well-being and did not boost cognitive or emotional function. The study by economists including Greg J. Duncan suggested other approaches may be necessary to address childhood poverty effectively.

stories.headline: Gunman Searched for N.F.L. Offices in Attack That Killed 4
stories.summary: A gunman, Shane Tamura, drove over 2,500 miles to attack the NFL headquarters in Manhattan, killing four people including a police officer and a financial executive. Authorities found a manifesto blaming the NFL for brain disease and cognitive decline, relating to chronic traumatic encephalopathy (C.T.E.) from football. The incident led to increased scrutiny of brain injuries in the sport and the shooter's motivations.

stories.headline: Mayor: Gunman took wrong elevator to NFL
stories.summary: A note found in the wallet of the man suspected of killing four people at a Manhattan office building before killing himself alleged downplaying the dangers of CTE. The gunman, Didarul Islam, was a former New York City police officer who had a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head trauma in contact sports such as football. The NFL has acknowledged proof of links to brain injury but denies liability. Officials described the shooting as unspeakable violence and expressed gratitude to the law enforcement officers involved.

stories.headline: More than 60,000 people killed in Gaza war, local health officials say
stories.summary: Local health authorities in Gaza report that more than 60,000 Palestinians have been killed in the ongoing Israeli military campaign. The deaths include patients and caregivers affected by the collapse of Gaza's infrastructure due to the conflict. The health ministry-run Gaza health sector distinguishes between civilian and combatant casualties but acknowledges the conflict has severely impacted hospitals and health services, according to experts and scientists.

stories.headline: Trump says Epstein 'stole' young women from Mar-a-Lago spa
stories.summary: President Donald Trump claimed that Jeffrey Epstein 'stole' young women who worked at the Mar-a-Lago spa, referencing a highly scrutinized past relationship. Trump denied knowledge of wrongdoing and suggested Epstein misled him. The claim was made amid questions about Trump's team trying to restrict testimonies and maintain immunity from prosecution related to Epstein. The story highlights ongoing controversies around Epstein's abuse allegations and Trump's associations.

stories.headline: Shapiro expands attacks on moves by Trump
stories.summary: Governor Josh Shapiro criticized President Donald Trump's administration for plans to review Independence Park exhibits and for moves to defund Planned Parenthood. Shapiro, representing Democratic opposition, announced plans to sue the Trump administration to protect these areas. He emphasized that recent public dissatisfaction with Trump and GOP patterns was especially strong regarding Medicaid cuts and opposition to protecting freedom and education rights.

stories.headline: State consultant promoted visas
stories.summary: One of Secretary of State Diego Morales' companions, Raju Chinthala, was involved in promoting visa activity by allegedly using a no-bid business consulting contract during Morales' trip to India. Chinthala was paid $8,000 monthly for a 10-month contract to investigate and coordinate international business engagement and help advise Morales' office. The trip included economic development efforts and Chinthala appeared to spend part of the time seeking foreign investment for an unrelated project in Indiana, including an EB-5 visa program linked to President Trump's administration proposals.

stories.headline: Court docs: Neighbor shot two brothers
stories.summary: James Holder was injured when a bullet was lodged in his spine, requiring a brace to help him breathe following a shooting incident on July 22. His brother Edward remains in critical condition. The shooting was allegedly committed by Holder's next-door neighbor after a dispute. The neighbor has not been arrested but faces formal charges including aggravated battery and battery by means of a deadly weapon. The neighbor's mailbox is near the victim's home, and the incident followed previous tensions between the men.

stories.headline: MLS expansion hopes stall
stories.summary: Despite initial enthusiasm and rapid progress, the effort to bring a Major League Soccer team and stadium to Indianapolis has slowed down significantly. Lawmakers, city leaders, and investors have yet to reach an agreement or establish a timeline. While there is continued hope to move forward, uncertainties remain about financial details and stadium costs. The Capital Improvement Board is now seeking a contractor to provide more accurate estimates for the stadium's construction costs.

stories.headline: Ozempic Maker's Headwinds Sink Stock
stories.summary: Shares of Novo Nordisk plunged after the Danish company that boomed on weight-loss drugs forecast a gloomier future due to competition from rival pharmaceutical companies and regulatory challenges. The anticipated slowdown in sales growth and difficult competitive landscape caused investors to lose confidence, driving stock prices down significantly. The company is now facing a need to navigate market pressures and regulatory hurdles to sustain its growth trajectory.

stories.headline: EPA Moves to Rescind A Landmark Finding On Greenhouse Gases
stories.summary: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced it is proposing to rescind its 2009 declaration that greenhouse gas emissions from power plants and other sources endanger public health and welfare. The move aims to take a swing at limiting climate change regulations by shifting the basis of the agency's authority on greenhouse gases. Critics argue this rollback could undermine efforts to address climate change and reverse progress made on emissions controls under previous administrations.

stories.headline: Merger To Create Pan-U.S. Railroad
stories.summary: Union Pacific plans to buy Norfolk Southern in a $71.5 billion merger that would create the largest rail network in the U.S. The deal, which still needs regulatory approval, would join 50,000 miles of railroad tracks from New Jersey to California and reduce costs and supply chain inefficiencies. Executive leaders from Union Pacific project improved shipping and more efficient supply chains, signaling a major change in the U.S. rail industry landscape.

stories.headline: Why the Fighting in Gaza Won't Stop
stories.summary: Israel wrapped up its campaign against Iran-linked Hezbollah fighters in 12 days but has not ended the war with Hamas after nearly two years of conflict. The violence and hunger crisis have eroded Israel's standing on the global stage. Over two million people inside Gaza are struggling to find food, shelter, and medical care amid ongoing fighting. Palestinian and Israeli leaders express different views on prospects for lasting peace, while many civilians face dire humanitarian conditions.

stories.headline: As Gunman Stalked Building, Workers Hid, Erected Barriers
stories.summary: A rampage killer who fired four shots in a Manhattan office building left a suicide note saying he believed he had CTE and blamed the National Football League for his brain injuries. The shooter carried a rifle and caused panic among workers at the landmark New York office tower, which is home to prestigious firms such as private-equity giant Blackstone and KPMG. Security measures were quickly put in place, with employees hiding and barricading themselves to stay safe during the incident.

stories.headline: Gunman was trying to get to NFL offices
stories.summary: In New York, a gunman who claimed mental health problems and CTE blamed the NFL for his condition and intended to target the league's headquarters. The shooter, Shane Tamura, caused panic in a Manhattan office tower and shot several people in the lobby before being killed by police. Investigators found no evidence linking the attacker's grievances to NFL players' brain trauma claims. Tamura had a history of mental illness and was diagnosed post-mortem with signs related to CTE.

stories.headline: Council hires IA consultant
stories.summary: The Decatur City Council voted 3-0 to hire Stratford Highland LLC as an independent contractor to oversee Internal Affairs investigations for the Decatur Police Department. This is part of Chief Torry Mack's ongoing reorganization, including renaming Internal Affairs. The contract will cost $110,000. Stratford Highland is led by Al Anger, former colleague of Mack from the Birmingham Police Department. The move aims to restructure investigations and bring new policies.

stories.headline: Federal funds released as classes start
stories.summary: Alabama schools will receive approximately $52 million in federal education funds, nearly $3 million of which is locally allocated. The funds support Title II-A programs, summer and after-school programs, English language learners, and migrant students. The funding aims to improve educational equity and help disadvantaged students, according to Lawrence County Schools Superintendent Jon Bret Smith. About $300,000 will assist Lawrence County Schools' operations and rural district needs.

stories.headline: Ready for science
stories.summary: The Decatur Public Library hosted a Sensational Science Summer Show led by Professor Graybeard (John Wicks) as part of its Summer Reads program. Dozens of local children participated in color-themed experiments inside the Youth Services Room. The Summer Reads program is designed to help students avoid losing reading skills over summer with themes like "Color Our World." Various local organizations contributed to the educational experience.

stories.headline: Rescored STAARs shoot up
stories.summary: Dallas ISD asked Texas to double-check STAAR tests after finding many missed questions were graded incorrectly. About a third of the reviewed exams showed improved scores when rescored by humans instead of computers. This has sparked discussions about potential impacts on students' academic standings and raised concerns about the fairness and accuracy of automated scoring systems used by the state.

stories.headline: Gunman meant to target NFL
stories.summary: A man who killed four people in a Manhattan office tower was found to have targeted the National Football League headquarters specifically. The gunman blamed his mental health problems on the NFL and intended to attack the league's headquarters. Investigations revealed that the suspect, carrying a note, suffered traumatic brain injuries linked to chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). The attack heightened concerns about safety at prominent sports venues and the long-term effects of brain injuries in athletes.

stories.headline: President is optimistic for future
stories.summary: Ethan Casson has become the new president of the Dallas Mavericks, bringing extensive experience from his previous roles with the Timberwolves and 49ers. Casson aims to leverage his expertise to help the Mavericks with business operations and pursue strategic initiatives including developing new basketball-specific arenas and entertainment districts. The franchise remains optimistic about growth under his leadership.

stories.headline: ICE exceeded holding times, families say
stories.summary: Immigration detention centers in Dallas are reportedly overcrowded and have held migrants, including families, for longer than legally allowed. The Department of Homeland Security denies poor conditions allegations, claiming their facilities meet required standards and do not operate as holding facilities. However, family members and interviews indicate extended detention times and overcrowding issues persist, raising concerns about detainee welfare and compliance with federal rules.

stories.headline: Key GOP officials back map
stories.summary: Republican leaders in Texas, including the state Senate Republican chairman, are supporting the current congressional redistricting map amid criticism and legal challenges from the Department of Justice and Democratic officials. The GOP argues that the districts were drawn legally and fairly, whereas opponents claim some districts violate voting rights and the constitution. The debate continues as hearings and legal proceedings unfold.

stories.headline: Hello to hotter days ahead in North Texas
stories.summary: North Texas is experiencing a heat wave with temperatures reaching around 100 degrees, making it the first triple-digit day of the summer for the Dallas-Fort Worth area. The National Weather Service forecasts even hotter days ahead with highs possibly hitting 103 and heat indices reaching 108. A heat advisory has been extended to help residents prepare and stay safe from extreme heat conditions.

stories.headline: Model of Moscow home built for Kohberger trial
stories.summary: As part of the Bryan Kohberger murder trial, a not-to-scale model of the home at 1122 King Road in Moscow was constructed to demonstrate crime scene details. The trial centers on Kohberger pleading guilty to four murders of University of Idaho students. The model supports prosecution evidence and helps illustrate events leading to the deaths, amidst defense objections regarding its evidentiary use.

stories.headline: Parents, toddler identified in fatal Nampa plane crash
stories.summary: Officials identified the victims of a fatal plane crash in Nampa, where a family consisting of a married couple and their toddler died. The crash occurred near Nampa airport and the victims included Brandon LeRoy, Jestene LeRoy, and their child. Investigation revealed the victims died either at the scene or in hospital, with condolences extended by local coroners.

stories.headline: Authorities worry as red-light running rises in Boise area
stories.summary: Authorities report an increase in red-light running in the Treasure Valley, raising concerns over traffic accidents and injuries. Though various local governments have shown reluctance to use red-light cameras due to privacy issues and legislative bans, concerns remain about enforcing traffic safety and reducing traffic-related infractions and accidents.

stories.headline: New Caldwell homes plagued by mold, defects, safety issues
stories.summary: A recent report reveals numerous problems such as mold, poor ventilation, structural defects, and safety issues affecting new homes in Caldwell and Southwest Idaho. Former building official David Wardell highlights that these issues include inadequate air conditioning, water intrusion, and non-compliance with homebuilding safety rules, exacerbating housing shortage problems and jeopardizing occupant health and safety.

stories.headline: Police ask for tips on attack at park
stories.summary: Police in West Fork are encouraging the public to submit information and evidence related to a double homicide that occurred at Devil's Den State Park. One witness has provided a photo of a person of interest in the case. The victims, identified as Clinton David Brink and Cristen Amanda Brink, were fatally attacked while hiking with their daughters. Authorities released a composite sketch and request public help to identify the individual in the image, who appears to be wearing a black shirt, dark pants, and a ball cap.

stories.headline: Union Pacific proposes buy of railroad for $85B
stories.summary: Union Pacific announced a proposed acquisition of Norfolk Southern in an $85 billion deal that would create the first transcontinental railroad in the United States. The merger would combine railroads with more than 50,000 miles of track and connections to major ports on both coasts. The combined company aims to maintain 1,300 miles of track in Arkansas and operate the nation's largest terminal in Memphis. The proposal would merge the two rail networks in the Western and Eastern United States under a unified operation.

stories.headline: Ban abortion shield laws, says attorney general
stories.summary: Arkansas Attorney General Tim Griffin joined a coalition of 15 other attorneys general calling on Congressional leaders to prevent anti-abortion shield laws, which protect states banning abortion from prosecution by other states with different laws. Griffin expressed concern over abortion drug use and the ability of such laws to shield people from legal action across state lines. The move follows the U.S. Supreme Court's decision allowing states greater abortion restrictions, intensifying the debate about interstate legal conflicts related to abortion rights.

stories.headline: AG: No law broken yet by all-white community
stories.summary: Arkansas Attorney General Tim Griffin indicated that a preliminary review of a predominantly white community in Sharp County revealed no evidence of breaking the law in its formation. A spokesperson clarified that the review is ongoing following a report concerning the 'whites-only' nature of the community. Griffin emphasized the importance of continued examination before drawing conclusions about potential legal violations related to community demographics.

stories.headline: EPA proposes repeal of climate declaration
stories.summary: The Biden administration has proposed revoking a scientific finding that has been the central basis for U.S. action to regulate greenhouse gas emissions and fight climate change. The Environmental Protection Agency's rule rescinds a 2009 declaration that determined carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases endanger public health and welfare, which underpinned a host of regulations under the Clean Air Act. This action aims to remove regulatory authority on vehicles, power plants, and other pollution sources, sparking concerns from environmental groups but support from industry and conservative lawmakers.

stories.headline: More Than a Wing and a Prayer?
stories.summary: Johnson has offered more talk than solutions to the city’s increasingly dire finances. The article analyzes whether his rollout of some new revenue sources on Tuesday indicates a new approach to addressing the city's financial challenges.

stories.headline: Northwestern Hopes Intimate New Football Stadium Will Be a Game-Changer
stories.summary: Northwestern University is optimistic that its new intimate football stadium will significantly impact their sports program and fan experience, aiming to be a game-changer for the team.

stories.headline: Fans Flock to Sandberg’s Statue to Pay Tribute: ‘Wrigley Field’s Never Gonna Be the Same’
stories.summary: Fans gathered to pay their respects to legendary Cubs second baseman Ryne Sandberg outside Wrigley Field. The tribute marks a significant moment for the community as they react to the loss of the baseball legend.

stories.headline: EPA Move to Go After Root of Clean Air Act a 'Handout to Fossil Fuel Industry'
stories.summary: The EPA is taking steps to target the root of the Clean Air Act, a move criticized as a handout to the fossil fuel industry. The story includes local reactions regarding this development and its potential impact.

stories.headline: Will becoming a city help Brownsville and its neighbors thrive?
stories.summary: At the corner of Northwest 27th Avenue and 54th Street in Brownsville sits a plot of land that was supposed to have a grocery store atop it. It has changed hands many times and suffered through many broken promises, according to Kenneth Kilpatrick, who says incorporation could help Brownsville and nearby areas thrive by encouraging better entertainment and shopping options for the community.

stories.headline: 'Not some boujee yacht club.' Miami Yacht Club teaches kids to sail
stories.summary: The Miami Yacht Club honors its century-long mission of cultivating kids' independence and water skills by teaching sailing to children as young as age 5 during their summer camp. Katie Flood-Reiss, a former member and counselor, emphasizes the club's focus on safety and accessibility rather than exclusivity, aiming to support children and their families in learning sailing and enjoying the water safely.

stories.headline: Cancer patients in Haiti face death sentence due to distance, gangs, and a lack of resources
stories.summary: Jean Fritz Dieu, 42, battled an aggressive cancer tumor while living in remote mountainous regions controlled by gangs in Haiti. Receiving radiation treatment through a South Florida-based charity, Flying High 4 Haiti, Fritz Dieu's story highlights the severe challenges cancer patients in Haiti face, including dangerous travel and limited medical resources, leading to grim survival odds.

stories.headline: Florida has no formal hurricane plan for Alligator Alcatraz
stories.summary: Florida's state officials confirmed there is no formal, completed plan for handling a hurricane at Alligator Alcatraz, the new immigrant detention site in the Everglades. Despite requests and a press conference, the Florida Department of Emergency Management has not confirmed such a plan exists. Concerns remain about the safety of detainees and staff in case of disasters such as hurricanes.

stories.headline: Missouri AG investigating Page
stories.summary: The Missouri Attorney General is investigating St. Louis County Executive Sam Page's use of public money on an April ballot proposition. The probe focuses on county voter outreach and was confirmed after Page hired an attorney. Officials emphasize that the laws do not allow taxpayer money to be used to advocate for or against campaign issues. Missouri Highway Patrol troopers visited Page's office as part of the inquiry, and senior staffers remain in place while the investigation proceeds.

stories.headline: Gunman in NY was targeting offices of NFL
stories.summary: A man who killed four people at a Manhattan NFL office building claimed his attack was motivated by a brain disease and a note blaming the NFL for players' brain injuries. The suspect brought a gun elevator in the wrong place and fatally shot four people including an off-duty New York City police officer. The investigation revealed he had no history of playing football but was aware of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), which influenced his motives outlined in a handwritten note.

stories.headline: Court: City must pay man $2.5 million
stories.summary: The city of St. Louis has been ordered by a Missouri appeals court to pay $2.5 million to Michael Holmes, who spent five years in prison after wrongful arrest by two former city police officers. The ruling holds the city responsible for Holmes's wrongful conviction related to drug charges in 2003. Holmes was later acquitted following an internal police misconduct investigation that found the officers engaged in repeated misconduct. The decision represents a significant legal affirmation of accountability in police cases.

stories.headline: BAR K, Dog Park Closes Doors
stories.summary: Bar K, a combination bar and dog park located in St. Louis, has permanently closed its doors due to financial challenges. The bar, previously expanding to Kansas City and Oklahoma City, faced issues with membership renewals and was unable to provide refunds despite customer concerns. Co-founders Leli Dodell and Dave Hensley cited the business's unsustainability as the reason for ceasing operations, and staff were informed about the closure after the company stopped issuing refunds.

stories.headline: Comments earn judge misconduct complaint
stories.summary: Federal judges faced increased scrutiny as the Justice Department filed a formal misconduct complaint against Judge James Boasberg for his alleged anti-Trump bias. The complaint followed Boasberg's comments made during a closed-door judges meeting, where he was accused of creating a 'constitutional crisis' by ignoring court rulings. The administration widened its efforts to challenge judges seen as acting against federal actions such as immigration enforcement.

stories.headline: New codes let campus free speech flourish for first time in 20 years
stories.summary: Colleges and universities across the United States are adopting new free speech codes that protect students' rights to express unpopular opinions, reversing previous restrictive policies. The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression reported an increase in institutions promoting free speech, marking a significant change in higher education over the last two decades.

stories.headline: Rhetoric on Taiwan defense raises doubts as alliance hangs in balance
stories.summary: Uncertainty surrounds the U.S.-Taiwan alliance after sharp rhetoric about defense commitments. Analysts note mixed signals from leaders including Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia and Chinese President Xi Jinping, casting doubt on the level of military support Taiwan can expect in potential conflicts. The Biden administration is reviewing its China policy amid these tensions.

stories.headline: Putin says America indebted to Russia for birth, survival
stories.summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that the United States owes its birth and survival during the Civil War to Russia’s contributions. This narrative emphasizes historical ties between the two nations and suggests humility and gratitude in peace talks despite ongoing geopolitical tensions. Putin highlighted Russia’s aid during the American Civil War and criticized American narratives of history and foreign policy.

stories.headline: Maxwell offers deal in Epstein client probe
stories.summary: Ghislaine Maxwell, convicted of serving Jeffrey Epstein’s trafficking network, is offering to testify in exchange for immunity and other terms in congressional probes of Epstein’s associates. Maxwell’s attorney informed lawmakers she won’t answer questions without immunity, and the House has subpoenaed her and Justice Department files as part of ongoing investigations into Epstein’s crimes and network.

stories.headline: IMF upgrades outlook for U.S., global economy
stories.summary: The International Monetary Fund has improved its economic forecast for the United States and the global economy. The report indicates U.S. trade policies are less damaging than previously expected, signaling a more positive economic outlook for the year.

stories.headline: Court showdown over tariff authority threatens to shake Trump's trade deals
stories.summary: President Trump's unilateral power to impose tariffs on other nations will be hotly debated before a federal appeals court, potentially affecting the large trade deals already in place. The case involves the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit and administration attorneys contesting a May ruling that struck down Mr. Trump's sweeping tariff orders under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The outcome could determine the extent of presidential power over tariffs and its impact on constituents and businesses.

stories.headline: Gunman thought he had football brain injury
stories.summary: A man who opened fire in a Manhattan office building in July carried a letter claiming he suffered from traumatic brain injury and blamed the National Football League for his struggles. Police identified the gunman as 27-year-old Shane Tamura, a former high school football player with a history of documented mental health issues. Authorities described his shooting as targeting people and injuring a fifth before dying on himself. Tamura's letter detailed his prolonged suffering from brain injury and implied it led to his violent actions.

stories.headline: At national parks, profound affection and deep concern
stories.summary: Tourists continue to visit America's national parks in vast numbers during summer, including Glacier, Mammoth Cave, and Zion National Parks. However, visitors and park staff express concern about the future due to potential budget cuts under the current administration. The National Park Service faces challenges including staff reductions and maintenance issues, which could affect visitor experience and preservation efforts. Despite uncertainties, parks remain treasured natural sites drawing large crowds.

stories.headline: Tax experts warn IRS's debt notices could be used to fire federal staff
stories.summary: The IRS has sent letters to federal workers warning about their tax debts, which tax experts say may be used to dismiss employees for not meeting eligibility criteria related to tax compliance. Privacy concerns arise as IRS has generally prevented sharing information about individuals with external agencies, but claims those with outstanding debts could face termination in government jobs. Legal experts criticize the approach for potentially being unfair and not allowing sufficient time or information to respond.

stories.headline: Trump's line on China shifts focus from security to trade
stories.summary: The Trump administration has shifted its approach to China, moving from emphasizing security issues to focusing on trade. This includes efforts to dissolve Taiwan's leader from mainland Chinese supporters and removing export controls on China. The changes come amid high-stakes trade talks and evolving diplomatic relations, with concerns over national security and economic impact driving policy shifts. The administration's renewed focus is aimed at addressing economic competition and trade balance with China.

stories.headline: EPA aims to topple climate law pillar
stories.summary: The Environmental Protection Agency unveiled a proposal to rescind a landmark legal opinion that underpins many emission regulations. This move would end EPA's authority to curb greenhouse gases emitted by vehicles and heavy trucks, removing controls on pollution contributions from those sources. Critics say the proposal would severely limit EPA's ability to regulate greenhouse gas emissions and environmental protections. If enacted, it would affect legal battles over climate policies and reduce the agency's ability to enforce climate-related regulations.

stories.headline: More than 60,000 lives lost in Gaza
stories.summary: The number of Palestinians killed in the latest military campaign in Gaza has surpassed 60,000, according to local health authorities. The Gaza Health Ministry, which is widely supported by the United Nations and other international bodies, is likely undercounting deaths due to exclusion of combatants and civilians killed by Israeli forces. The majority of deaths are women and children, with Gaza largely cut off from outside aid like food delivered through tunnels blocked by Israel. The Gaza Health Ministry continues to report deaths amid the ongoing conflict, stating that Gaza is war-torn and heavily impacted by Israeli actions.

stories.headline: U.S. and EU aerospace rivals unite on trade
stories.summary: The U.S. and European Union aerospace competitors have come together to address trade issues impacting their industry. This collaboration marks a significant development in international trade relations within the aerospace sector.

stories.headline: Ithaca man charged with murder in stabbing
stories.summary: An Ithaca man was arrested and charged with second-degree murder following a fatal stabbing on the night of July 24. The suspect, Autreyu L. Massaline, 25, was taken into custody around 10 p.m. on July 26 after investigations by the Ithaca Police Department and New York State Police Major Crimes Unit. Massaline was arraigned and remanded to the Tompkins County Jail.

stories.headline: NY sues Trump over demand for food aid info
stories.summary: New York has joined a multi-state lawsuit against the Trump administration to challenge demands for personal data on individuals receiving monthly food aid via SNAP. The suits argue that these demands for detailed personal information violate privacy and are unlawful actions by the administration. The federal government has compelled states to provide extensive documentation on food aid recipients since 2020.

stories.headline: A new month of moments
stories.summary: Ithaca is preparing for a vibrant stretch of events throughout August. The Downtown Ithaca Summer Sidewalk Sale runs from July 31 to August 3, featuring discounted merchandise and inviting shoppers to explore local businesses. Other events include Circus Culture’s Summer Tour with free performances and the return of the Ithaca Artist Market on August 2, showcasing over 80 regional artists.

stories.headline: Migrant families displaced after fatal fire
stories.summary: A deadly fire in an Austin apartment building displaced dozens, including migrant families. One mother, Karen Jimenez, barely escaped with her children. The blaze occurred in an 18-unit building and took the life of one resident, while many others, particularly those without legal status or resources, face challenges in recovery. Authorities continue to assess the aftermath and support affected families.

stories.headline: Second to none
stories.summary: Ryne Sandberg, legendary Cubs Hall of Famer known for his rare blend of power, speed, and defense, died after recurrence of cancer at age 65. Sandberg had battled metastatic prostate cancer since 2004, enduring extensive treatment while continuing to inspire fans with his legacy. He was a revered figure in Chicago baseball, remembered for his skill and character on and off the field.

stories.headline: Group aims new effort at 'rational' redistricting
stories.summary: A bipartisan group plans to launch a voter initiative aimed at reforming the Illinois Constitution to reduce partisanship in legislative redistricting. The proposal, targeting Illinois House and State Senate boundaries, seeks a more streamlined process to avoid gerrymandering that has entrenched political influence. The effort will be formally unveiled at a discussion hosted by the Lincoln Forum and the Union League Club of Chicago.

stories.headline: Trump EPA proposes rule rollback
stories.summary: The Trump administration's EPA proposed revoking a science-based determination on pollution fueling climate change harms. The rollback would eliminate landmark federal rules aimed at protecting the environment by tightening regulations on emissions from vehicles, power plants and other sources. Critics argue the move ignores scientific evidence and could worsen climate impacts such as toxic algae blooms and extreme weather events.

stories.headline: Harvard may be facing a no-win situation
stories.summary: Harvard University is grappling with challenges related to maintaining academic freedom and autonomy while addressing concerns from its community and critics. Recent changes in university offices focus on issues such as LGBTQ student life and minority students. However, the Trump administration's push for oversight and faculty hiring policies further complicate the university's efforts to balance diverse opinions and political pressures.

stories.headline: EPA aims to kill key weapon on climate
stories.summary: The Environmental Protection Agency, under the Trump administration, announced plans to revoke the scientific determination that underpins its authority to regulate greenhouse gas emissions, specifically targeting limits on emissions from cars, power plants, and other sources. This move effectively removes regulatory powers established under the Clean Air Act to combat climate change, sparking concerns about environmental and public health consequences.

stories.headline: Housing affordability unites foes
stories.summary: Housing affordability has become a critical issue across Massachusetts, with opposition groups led by politicians like Senator Tim Scott pushing legislation to address the problem. The growing housing crisis in the 2024 elections is seen as a major concern statewide. The legislative efforts have united diverse groups aiming to improve access and affordability of housing in the state, highlighting the urgency to find sustainable solutions.

stories.headline: Mass. and Cass chaos encroaching on frustrated South End neighbors
stories.summary: Residents in the South End are increasingly frustrated with public drug use and dealing, which continues despite organized efforts to address the issue by city and state officials. The situation has raised concerns among neighbors about safety and quality of life as outreach programs and law enforcement strive to tackle the ongoing public health crisis involving substance abuse.

stories.headline: Lawsuit calls DraftKings' ads deceptive
stories.summary: A major Boston-based online gambling company, DraftKings, faces a federal lawsuit accusing it of using misleading ads to encourage quick large bets, which public health advocates say fuel gambling addictions. The lawsuit highlights concerns over the expansion of gambling options, including online casinos and sports betting, and criticizes the targeting of vulnerable populations in Massachusetts and other states.

stories.headline: Tensions revealed in flood response
stories.summary: Following a devastating July 4 flash flood in Hill Country, newly surfaced texts and emails reveal frustrations of Kerrville officials with the county's flood response. Mayor Joe Herring Jr. and emergency coordinators reportedly experienced communication issues, with some city employees starting action before county coordination, and officials feeling sidelined despite an invitation to a related state briefing. This highlights the challenges and tensions in managing flood emergencies at different government levels.

stories.headline: Downtown abuzz with rooftop bees
stories.summary: Urban beekeeping is thriving in Houston, with over 750,000 pollinators living atop city skyscrapers. Managed by Alvéole, several beehive communities exist across downtown commercial buildings, enhancing urban biodiversity. Experts and companies emphasize the health and productivity benefits of these hives, with beekeepers like Brian VanMiddendorp tending to them on properties such as the Norton Rose Fulbright Tower, enabling nature to coexist with city life.

stories.headline: New law for schools draws joy, wrath — and lawsuits
stories.summary: A new Texas law mandating the display of the Ten Commandments in schools faces legal challenges and causes mixed reactions. While some see it as an important faith expression, others worry about the negative impact on inclusivity and student wellbeing. The law, authored by Republican Senator Phil King, has resulted in lawsuits and ongoing debate about the separation of church and state in education.

stories.headline: AG bill vote not seen as a conflict for senators
stories.summary: The Texas Senate is set to vote on a bill that would expand the attorney general's power to prosecute election crimes, considered by some as a potential conflict of interest for attorney general candidates Senate hopefuls. Despite concerns raised by legal experts and ethics attorneys about conflicts and financial interests, the bill, supported by high-profile politicians including Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, is moving forward amid unusual political circumstances.

stories.headline: Real ID backlog creates 97-day wait
stories.summary: Minnesota's Driver and Vehicle Services is significantly delayed in processing Real ID applications due to a shortage of staff and increasing demands. With only 24 employees handling hundreds of thousands of applications, the wait time for a Real ID has reached 97 days. The TSA began requiring Real IDs for domestic flights in May, leading to a surge in applications. DVS aims to process around 48,000 applications monthly but is struggling to keep up, causing frustration among applicants.

stories.headline: UNH will cut plans that affect 600,000
stories.summary: UnitedHealth Group announced it will drop Medicare Advantage health plans covering over 600,000 people as part of efforts to reverse financial losses. The company aims to reset its financial strategies amid rising healthcare costs and shareholder pressure. The cutback primarily affects health plans where seniors have a broad choice of providers. UnitedHealth’s healthcare arm is the largest provider of Medicare Advantage plans in the U.S.

stories.headline: 'Worst-case scenario of famine' in Gaza
stories.summary: International authorities warn of a severe famine crisis developing in the Gaza Strip, with experts predicting widespread death if immediate measures are not taken. The situation follows nearly 22 months of conflict resulting in massive displacement and humanitarian pauses. A protest by Israeli activists in Tel Aviv highlighted concerns regarding food distribution and the forced displacement of Palestinians.

stories.headline: Cyber criminals hit city of St. Paul
stories.summary: St. Paul's digital infrastructure was shut down in a cyberattack, affecting city libraries, red centers, payment systems, and 911 emergency response systems, although some emergency services remained functional. Mayor Melvin Carter declared a state of emergency to allow city departments to mobilize support from local, state, and federal officials. The attack was a coordinated digital assault by a sophisticated external actor, and the FBI along with state and local cybersecurity firms are investigating to contain the threat.

stories.headline: State orders security review at State Capitol
stories.summary: Minnesota officials are considering expanding the emergency alert system for legislators following last month's shootings of two lawmakers and a recent break-in at the State Capitol. The Minnesota House and Senate are also discussing changes to improve safety, including allowing members to use up to $4,500 for home security upgrades from their respective chambers' funds. Recent security concerns include a burglary at the Capitol involving a man who propped open a door during a break-in attempt.

stories.headline: Governor races: Referendums on Trump vs. Dems
stories.summary: More than 36 states are preparing for high-stakes gubernatorial elections, which could determine whether the Democratic Party maintains or loses ground amid ongoing political tensions. Key potential 2028 presidential contenders are involved, and the outcomes may influence national political dynamics and strategies for both Republicans and Democrats.

stories.headline: Hunger in Gaza: One meal a day
stories.summary: Due to market closures and cash liquidity crises, Gazan families face overwhelming hardships, with parents forced to choose which child receives food each day. The story highlights the dire situation of Gaza residents such as Amal Nassar, an English teacher, who struggle to afford basic necessities amid ongoing conflict and blockade.

stories.headline: Eerie images leave viewers seeing double
stories.summary: French-Canadian photographer François Brunelle has documented over 250 pairs of doppelgängers worldwide over 25 years. His photography series, "I'm Not a Lookalike!", captures startling resemblances of unrelated people, exploring the concept of doubles or doppelgängers in folklore and modern usage.

stories.headline: How will EU trade deal hit wallets?
stories.summary: As the United States imposes a 15% tariff on most imports from the European Union, prices for imported cars, pharmaceuticals, and apparel may rise, impacting consumer wallets. Analysts describe the agreement announced on July 27 as beneficial to President Donald Trump, with expectations of higher inflation and increased costs for U.S. consumers as a result.

stories.headline: Death toll in war-torn Gaza reaches 60,000
stories.summary: A famine crisis is escalating in the Gaza Strip amidst ongoing conflict, with the death toll surpassing 60,000 due to starvation and violence. The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification has raised alarms about the severity of the situation, with the World Food Programme highlighting challenges in humanitarian aid delivery. The international community is urged to increase efforts to alleviate food shortages and address the worsening humanitarian crisis.

stories.headline: Traverse City heroes are hoping for justice
stories.summary: Two men who intervened during a stabbing spree at a northern Michigan supermarket are seeking justice after the suspect was charged with terrorism and assault with intent to murder. Bradford James Gille was arraigned in court, while Matt Kolakowski, one of the men who confronted the suspect, spoke about the traumatic event. They hope their efforts in stopping the violence will lead to appropriate legal consequences for the assailant.

stories.headline: NO ANSWERS YET IN JIMMY HOFFA CASE
stories.summary: Fifty years after the disappearance of Teamsters union boss Jimmy Hoffa, authorities still have no answers. Hoffa vanished outside a popular Oakland County restaurant in 1975 after scheduling a meeting with mobsters. Despite solid alibis and investigations indicating involvement by others, the mystery persists with no resolution. Law enforcement asserts that the right individuals were suspected but concrete proof remains elusive.

stories.headline: Military exercise brings troops — and economic impact — to state
stories.summary: More than 7,500 military personnel will converge on Michigan for Northern Strike 25-2, a major training exercise running from August 2 to 16. This event includes participants from 36 states and various international partners focusing on homeland security and defense scenarios. The exercise is expected to inject around $38 million into Michigan’s economy through military pay, travel, and local spending.

stories.headline: Mental health issues revealed while suspect is arraigned
stories.summary: Authorities have disclosed that Bradford James Gille, charged with stabbing 11 people in a Walmart in Traverse City, has a long history of mental illness and substance use. Gille was first hospitalized at age 14 and has been psychiatrically evaluated multiple times. Despite the tragedy, law enforcement and court officials continue to investigate the motives and details surrounding this violent attack.

stories.headline: Trump is getting the world economy he wants
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is achieving his goal of reshaping the world economy through trade partnerships and tariffs. The US has reached agreements with various countries and trade groups to impose tariffs, aiming to protect domestic interests and encourage beneficial economic policies. However, there are concerns that Trump's aggressive trade stance could potentially damage economic growth and global trade relations.

stories.headline: Mayor proposes lifting property tax rate
stories.summary: Chattanooga's mayor plans to raise about $50 million in revenue by increasing the city's property tax rate from 1.55% to 1.99%. The increase would help cover inflationary pressures, pay raises, and salary increases for police and firefighters. Mayor Tim Kelly also indicated the need for additional funds to support police and fire pay, with the council having passed a $345.2 million budget recently. Police Chief John Chambers raised concerns about potential staffing shortages due to pay disparities. The proposed tax rate increase could also fund pedestrian initiatives, down payment assistance for homebuyers, and new city benefits.

stories.headline: Rep. Greene calls crisis in Gaza a 'genocide'
stories.summary: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Northwest Georgia labeled the Gaza conflict a 'genocide' during her address at Capitol Hill. Greene criticized the ongoing conflict as involving starving and humanitarian crises and expressed concern about hostages. Despite skepticism from other lawmakers, Greene pressed the characterization of the situation as genocide, fueling the discourse on the humanitarian impact of the Gaza conflict.

stories.headline: UK head pressures Israel on ceasefire
stories.summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced that Britain would recognize the state of Palestine in September if Israel does not agree to a ceasefire with Hamas, intensifying diplomatic pressure on Israel. The announcement was part of a broader European effort to end the ongoing conflict that has put the Gaza Strip at risk of famine. Starmer's stance reflects growing political pressure amid images of starving children in Gaza and his own party's recoiling from them. The push aims to end the nearly two-year conflict between Israel and Hamas.

stories.headline: TVA board powers could go to CEO
stories.summary: President Donald Trump fired the remaining directors from the Tennessee Valley Authority board before nominations could be confirmed by the Senate, effectively temporarily transferring board powers to CEO Don Moul. Moul would gain authority over major spending, personnel, and policy decisions. The TVA, a federal utility agency, has historically been governed by a nine-member board. This change shifts TVA governance, potentially impacting the agency's direction. The board will continue to ensure TVA meets its federal electricity delivery mandates, but the CEO will now have the ability to act with greater autonomy.

stories.headline: Family Dollar had 22 citations, but not for structural issues
stories.summary: City inspectors found numerous citations related to litter, weeds, graffiti and parking violations at the Family Dollar store on Broadway in Kansas City, which partially collapsed and killed a man. However, none of the citations over the last four years involved structural concerns. Key officers of the company, including Clifford and Steven Trenton, pleaded guilty in court. The Arthur Fels Co., tied to the store, is a historic real estate company managing properties in Kansas City since the 1920s.

stories.headline: ‘Pure power grab’? Trump wants to gerrymander Kansas City
stories.summary: Missouri Republicans face pressure from President Donald Trump and a group of hard-right lawmakers aiming to gerrymander the state’s congressional districts to strengthen GOP control. Kansas City is targeted for redrawing with an additional U.S. House seat, seen as an effort to add a seat in Missouri and dilute Democratic influence. The plan, supported by Trump’s political team and Republican state lawmakers, has raised concerns about legal challenges and intensifying partisan divisions between Republicans and Democrats in the state.

stories.headline: ‘Couldn’t believe it’: KCK residents on fatal shooting
stories.summary: Residents in Kansas City's Argentine neighborhood recall the shock following a fatal shooting where Deputy Elijah Ming was killed during a standoff. Neighbors initially thought the gunfire was related to an accident, highlighting the unexpected nature of the violence in the usually quiet area. Dallas Lawver, a longtime local, described the community's disbelief and the rare occurrence of such incidents in the neighborhood, where residents had no reason to anticipate their street becoming the scene of a murder.

stories.headline: 3 new trustees join UK board, including ex-Lexington mayor
stories.summary: The University of Kentucky Board of Trustees has added three new members, including former Lexington mayor Jim Gray. The Board oversees the university’s financial and educational policies and consists of members appointed by various university and government bodies. Gray, a former mayor and current transportation secretary, along with other trustees like Clark Williams and Elaine Wilson, were appointed to serve terms extending through 2031.

stories.headline: Kentucky sues Trump to protect SNAP user privacy
stories.summary: Kentucky is suing the Trump administration for demanding states share personal information of people receiving Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits. The lawsuit is supported by 20 attorneys general, including Kentucky's, and accuses the administration of unlawfully sharing confidential SNAP data, potentially affecting over 575,000 Kentuckians. Governor Andy Beshear expressed his opposition to the policy and the state's actions to protect residents' privacy.

stories.headline: ICE ups surveillance of asylum seekers in Kentucky
stories.summary: The Central Kentucky mother Teresa, who had been summoned to an immigration office for alternatives to detention, is under surveillance by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) using the ATD-ISAP program. Teresa, who has a pending asylum case and fears ICE officials, has taken steps to remain in contact with her case worker while awaiting a permanent resident status. The child accompanying Teresa to the office was accidentally locked out, highlighting leading concerns about the treatment of asylum seekers.

stories.headline: Kentucky’s Comer on Epstein, potential governor run
stories.summary: Kentucky Representative James Comer plans to be in Florida in two weeks to depose Ghislaine Maxwell as part of ongoing controversy linked to Jeffrey Epstein. Comer criticized former President Trump and associates, emphasizing ongoing political tensions. He also addressed rumors about a potential governor run, stating his focus is on political accountability and transparency, while his committee remains transparent with the White House and others.

stories.headline: Hoffa’s labor legacy mixed after 50 years
stories.summary: The legacy of Jimmy Hoffa, the iconic Detroit union leader, remains controversial 50 years after his disappearance. Hoffa led the Teamsters from 1959 to 1971 and became a powerful labor figure. Despite his leadership prominence, criticisms of corruption and mob-connected activities persist. Hoffa's impact on labor organization is still a topic of debate among historians and labor experts.

stories.headline: At home on the ice
stories.summary: Anna Segedi's journey from a China orphanage to becoming a professional hockey player in the U.S. is highlighted. After arriving in the U.S. at 14, she developed as a hockey goalie and signed a two-year contract with the Professional Women's Hockey League. Her story underscores her growth in the sport and her gratitude for the opportunities she received, with many American connections supporting her path.

stories.headline: Energy grid upgrade bid irks property owners
stories.summary: Residents and property owners in Michigan are voicing complaints about new high-voltage transmission line projects that threaten farms and private properties, with concerns about limited ability to resist or influence the development. The projects, led by ITC Holdings, would cost about $624 million and stretch roughly 94 miles. Critics point to a lack of timely notifications and inadequate recourse against eminent domain and land seizure.

stories.headline: Trump’s EPA takes key step to nix last major auto emission rules
stories.summary: The Trump administration moved to eliminate the last major environmental regulation on the U.S. auto industry, proposing to end sixteen years of uncertainty for automakers and consumers by repealing a 2009 finding on greenhouse gas emissions. The EPA under Trump says previous administrations distorted science leading to high costs for families, and this step aligns with President Trump's broader efforts to dismantle federal fuel economy standards and zero-emission vehicle sales requirements.

stories.headline: How does denaturalization of citizens fit into Trump’s immigration policy?
stories.summary: Florida officials are at the forefront of the national discussion on President Donald Trump's immigration agenda, especially regarding denaturalization and deportation policies. The article discusses recent government actions and political rhetoric about revoking citizenship, particularly in cases involving alleged immigration fraud. It also mentions social media debate and ongoing legal considerations about stripping citizenship from people born outside the country who later gained citizenship through the naturalization process.

stories.headline: Is it bad that Jabil chose North Carolina?
stories.summary: The article examines Jabil's decision to build a new facility in North Carolina despite its headquarters being in Pinellas County, Florida. Experts weigh in on the pros and cons of the move, acknowledging the inevitable nature of it as Jabil aimed to create nearly 1,200 jobs. The piece also highlights the company's continued presence in Tampa Bay with its ongoing projects and leases.

stories.headline: Family reacts to arrest in ferry crash
stories.summary: Family members of Jose Castro, who was killed in the Clearwater Ferry crash three months ago, expressed their emotions and reactions following the arrest of local businessman Jeffry Knight. The Pinellas state attorney confirmed Knight, who posted bail, is not a flight risk. The family gathered with their lawyers to address reporters near the crash site, expressing sorrow and a wish that the charges against Knight were adequate to justice.

stories.headline: Charity: Gift reports weren’t needed
stories.summary: Lawmakers and DeSantis administration officials who attended a private golf resort event last year were told they did not need to disclose extravagant hotel rooms and custom golf bags as gifts to the state Ethics Commission. Under state law, gifts over $100 from state-created charities such as the Hope Florida Foundation must be reported, but the foundation president said these were not considered gifts and attendees’ assistance was more valuable. This clarification came after a Times/Herald report.

stories.headline: Apache women sue to halt land swap for copper mine
stories.summary: A group of Apache women filed a federal lawsuit in Washington, D.C., seeking to stop a land exchange that would allow a copper mine to be built on sacred land at Oak Flat. The lawsuit aims to prevent the U.S. Forest Service from signing over the land to Resolution Copper in exchange for other environmentally sensitive and culturally important lands. The land holds significant spiritual and cultural value to the Apache people and is located near the Tonto National Forest east of Phoenix.

stories.headline: Manhattan gunman claims NFL 'failed us'
stories.summary: A gunman who killed four people including a New York City police officer at a Manhattan building housing the National Football League headquarters and other major firms expressed resentment that the NFL had 'failed us.' Investigations showed the gunman may have aimed for the NFL but hit the wrong target. The suspect, Shane Tamura, left bullet holes in the building entrance with police barricades still lingering afterward.

stories.headline: Smoke, panic, frustration amid all the overcrowding
stories.summary: Inside the Eloy Detention Center, detainees experienced panic and frustration due to overcrowding and mismanagement. Maribel Alarcon Gomez and her roommate heard chaos and screaming as guards unlocked cell doors unusually early. Issues like the smell of rubber smoke caused by a malfunctioning microwave and general disorder highlight the crisis in the facility threatening detainees' lives.

stories.headline: Future looks dim for the LightHouse
stories.summary: LightHouse for the Blind and Visually Impaired, a nonprofit serving people in San Francisco for over 122 years, faces financial distress after losing over $17 million in property assets due to foreclosure on its Market Street property. The organization has laid off 40 employees and is planning to close its Humboldt County office and Berkeley campus next year. The nonprofit provides essential services like orientation training and classes for adults losing their sight, but faces uncertainty about its future operations and funding.

stories.headline: Loophole revives ‘Monster’ housing fight
stories.summary: San Francisco developers like Sam Moss have benefited from new state legislation that eases bureaucratic hurdles, leading to approval of a nine-story affordable housing building at 16th and Mission streets. The project, dubbed a "Monster in the Mission," faced delays but has been revived due to state reforms aimed at expediting housing construction. Moss expressed surprise at residents' appeal supporting his housing plan, which includes 136 studio and one-bedroom units plus on-site social services, aiming to provide for formerly homeless adults.

stories.headline: Bill extends S.F.’s natural gas ban to big renovations
stories.summary: San Francisco is set to extend its natural gas ban to major renovations of residential and commercial buildings, aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving public health. The ordinance requires "major renovation" projects to eliminate plans for replacing gas utilities with all-electric ones except in limited cases. The proposal is backed by Board of Supervisors President Rafael Mandelman and others, emphasizing the critical need to reduce greenhouse emissions by 2030. The bill also mandates considerations for heating, cooling, and lighting systems in renovated buildings.

stories.headline: Reforms may mean insurance rate hikes
stories.summary: California home insurance companies might soon request rate increases following regulatory reforms allowing the use of catastrophe models to evaluate risks. The California Department of Insurance enacted the Sustainable Insurance Strategy, making it easier for insurers to justify rate hikes as they expand wildfire risk coverage. Insurers have previously used backward-looking data but will now incorporate future risk predictions. This move is seen as critical for insurers to remain viable, despite concerns about potential premium cost increases for consumers.

stories.headline: He set the standard. They’ll set the table.
stories.summary: After a stroke in June, Lewiston's St. Martin de Porres shelter house manager Jimi Cutting has relied on dedicated volunteers to step in and help with daily operations, including cooking and managing evening duties. The community has rallied to support the shelter ensuring it continues to serve those in need despite staffing challenges following Jimi's health issues.

stories.headline: Maine rejects Justice request for voters’ personal data, list of election officials
stories.summary: The Trump administration's request for sensitive voter registration data across all 50 states, including Maine, has been denied by Maine's state officials. Maine has roughly 11,000 voters with duplicate registrations that the Trump administration wanted data on up to November 2022, but the state is citing privacy concerns and potential federal overreach. Maine argues that the federal request goes beyond constitutional limits and is politically motivated.

stories.headline: Sea Dogs pitcher Tolle on fast track to Red Sox
stories.summary: Portland Sea Dogs pitcher Payton Tolle has quickly made an impact after joining the team just over a month ago. With coaching from Sea Dogs manager Chad Epperson, Tolle is progressing rapidly and is on a fast track through the minor league system to potentially join the Boston Red Sox. Tolle is a left-handed, 6-foot-6, 250-pound 2024 draft pick who has shown promising performance early in his professional career.

stories.headline: South Portland author’s novel is Reese’s Book Club pick
stories.summary: Beck Dorey-Stein from South Portland has achieved notable recognition with her novel 'Spectacular Things' being selected as the July pick for actor Reese Witherspoon’s book club. The book is set in a fictional Maine town but includes recognizable Portland landmarks, with its opening scene involving a woman in labor stuck on a bridge. This acclaim has brought significant attention and publicity to the author and her work.

stories.headline: State orders CSX to install windscreen
stories.summary: The Maryland Department of the Environment is requiring CSX to build a large windscreen around coal storage piles at Curtis Bay to reduce harmful dust and air pollution affecting residents and environmental groups. The new permit replaces an older one from 2018 and mandates installation of improved water spray equipment at regular intervals to limit harmful emissions. While the community groups support efforts to control dust and protect public health, they remain skeptical about the effectiveness of the smaller windscreen and call for more stringent measures.

stories.headline: EPA moves to repeal landmark climate finding
stories.summary: President Donald Trump’s administration proposed revoking a scientific finding that has been the basis for U.S. action to regulate greenhouse gas emissions and fight climate change. The environmental Protection Agency rule would rescind a 2009 declaration that determined carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases endanger public health and welfare. The 'endangerment finding' is a legal underpinning of many climate regulations under the Clean Air Act for motor vehicles, power plants and other pollution sources. This move would be the largest deregulatory action in the history of America under EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin.

stories.headline: 'Ghost' students increasingly scamming Md., U.S. colleges
stories.summary: There is a growing problem of fraudulent college applicants, known as 'ghost' students, who generate fake applications using artificial intelligence and fabricated financial aid requests. These fake students disrupt operations at colleges by occupying spots and resources meant for genuine applicants. The U.S. Department of Education and colleges are trying to tighten security measures to prevent such fraud, but it remains a significant challenge especially given rising summer heat waves and administrative difficulties.

stories.headline: Johns Hopkins fights UnitedHealthcare over contract terms
stories.summary: Doctors at Johns Hopkins Medicine hospitals and facilities are unable to accept insurance from UnitedHealthcare due to contract negotiations that have stalled for seven months. The disagreement is over medical care reimbursement rates and prior authorization requirements. The current agreement has been extended multiple times during this period, but no new contract has been finalized. Johns Hopkins has warned patients about potential disruptions to care without a new contract.

stories.headline: Housing bill has parties getting along 14 for now
stories.summary: A Senate committee unanimously passed a bipartisan reform package aimed at addressing housing issues. Despite occasional partisan clashes and heated exchanges in Congress, there is movement towards bipartisan cooperation to tackle the nation’s housing crisis. The Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee unanimously advanced a major housing reform package, offering hope for bipartisan solutions in the near future.

stories.headline: 8.8 quake causes tsunami in Japan and Alaska, warnings on U.S. coast
stories.summary: A powerful 8.8 magnitude earthquake struck off Russia’s Far East early Wednesday, triggering a small tsunami affecting Japan and Alaska and prompting tsunami warnings for Hawaii, North and Central America, and the Pacific islands south toward New Zealand. Wave levels were below the alarming heights in Alaska but the risks prompted official warnings and alerts.

stories.headline: Divide among young Seattle-area voters grows along gender lines
stories.summary: A political divide between young women and men in Seattle-area has widened, with young women increasingly leaning left and young men shifting right. New data from Nielsen shows a rise in Democratic affiliation among young women from 2020 to 2025, while young men show less dramatic changes. The trend reflects significant shifts in political affiliation among younger generations and suggests challenges for political unity.

stories.headline: Boeing still burns cash, but CEO sees turnaround year in 2025
stories.summary: Boeing continues to burn cash but is seeing signs of recovery. The company reported a net loss of $612 million in the second quarter but views 2025 as a turnaround year. CEO Kelly Ortberg expressed optimism that ongoing momentum and improvements will strengthen culture and product quality. Boeing faces challenges including a recent incident involving an Alaska Airlines plane and is working on regaining customer confidence.

stories.headline: Ferguson: Inviting former aide on plane was 'stupid'
stories.summary: Governor Bob Ferguson apologized for inviting his former top aide Mike Webb on a state plane trip to Tri-Cities that included official business and a political fundraiser. Webb had resigned amid allegations of a hostile work environment. Ferguson acknowledged the invitation was 'pretty stupid' and defended his decision amid the tensions resurfaced by the incident and the aide's departure.

stories.headline: There's life in Seattle's new waterfront, if you know where to look
stories.summary: Seattle's new Waterfront Park, a decade and a half in the making with an $800 million investment, reconnects visitors with Puget Sound. The park features a rebuilt seawall allowing light to reach underwater life and various benches, overlooks, and tables decorated with plants. The project invites visitors to reconnect with the underwater ecosystem and enhances the waterfront experience in an urban setting.

stories.headline: Anti-hunger group: Death toll in Gaza reaches 60,000
stories.summary: The hunger crisis in Gaza is becoming severe with deaths reaching 60,000 amidst ongoing conflict. The starvation crisis could be formally classified as a famine, marking a catastrophic humanitarian situation. The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification has raised concern that famine thresholds have been met for food consumption in much of Gaza. The situation is exacerbated by restricted aid access despite international criticism. About 20% of Gaza's population is suffering extreme food shortages, with many children acutely malnourished.

stories.headline: Far fewer abortions occurring in Iowa
stories.summary: The number of abortions performed in Iowa has dropped dramatically since a restrictive new law took effect a year ago. The law, known as the "fetal heartbeat" law, bans most abortions once embryonic cardiac activity can be detected, typically around six weeks of pregnancy. This has contributed to a sharp decline in abortions in Iowa, but abortion providers report more Iowans are traveling to other states for procedures. Exceptions are included for rape, incest, and medical emergencies to preserve the life of the pregnant person or prevent major bodily function impairment. Preliminary state data shows abortions dropped 35% from 2023 to 2024 and are expected to fall further in 2025.

stories.headline: Sacramento pharmacy at center of health care policy debate
stories.summary: Sonya Frausto, owner of Ten Acres Pharmacy in Sacramento, announced her independent pharmacy would close after five years due to reimbursement issues with pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs). The closure highlights ongoing legislative debates in California about regulations to oversee PBMs and balance the interests of drugmakers, insurers, and pharmacies.

stories.headline: UCLA to pay $6.5M to settle suit over protests
stories.summary: UCLA agreed to pay $6.45 million to settle a federal lawsuit filed by three Jewish students and a medical school professor who accused the university of violating civil rights by enabling antisemitism during a pro-Palestinian encampment. The settlement also includes prohibiting UCLA from facilitating exclusion based on Jewish identity and funding for Jewish community projects.

stories.headline: Brothers killed in Esparto fireworks blast buried together
stories.summary: Ernesto Ramos and his younger brothers Jesus and Jhony Ramos, who were killed in an Esparto fireworks explosion, were buried together in a single grave with white caskets. The brothers shared many interests including youth sports and music. The cause of the deadly July 1 firework inferno remains unknown and the community mourns the loss.

stories.headline: 4 dead, including NYPD officer, in Midtown Manhattan shooting
stories.summary: Four people, including an NYPD officer, were killed in a shooting inside a New York City skyscraper housing the National Football League and Blackstone. The gunman, a 27-year-old from Las Vegas named Shane Tamura, opened fire before shooting himself. The incident caused multiple casualties and a police investigation is underway.

stories.headline: Filing questions DA’s tactics
stories.summary: The Washington County coroner alleges that District Attorney Jason Walsh coerced him into filing a fraudulent death certificate in 2022 that labeled a death as a homicide to benefit DA Walsh's election campaign. The coroner claims Walsh manipulated the court system to control autopsy rulings, which led to first-degree murder charges. Walsh denies these allegations.

stories.headline: Trump: Epstein ‘stole’ young women from Mar-a-Lago spa
stories.summary: President Donald Trump said Jeffrey Epstein 'stole' young women who worked for the spa at Mar-a-Lago, the latest in a series of comments responding to investigations into Epstein's sex trafficking network. Trump expanded on remarks made a day earlier when he claimed Epstein was 'stolen' from his private club. Virginia Giuffre, one of Epstein's most well-known victims, has spoken about the abuse.

stories.headline: Pa. Dems, public push for more documents
stories.summary: Western Pennsylvania Democrats and many voters are increasingly pressing the Trump administration to release more files related to Jeffrey Epstein. Pennsylvania Rep.
